Award.AwardTitle: Distributive Conjugal Transfer: a New Paradigm and Benchmark for Bacterial Horizontal Gene Transfer

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another accelerates the evolution of new strains and species. On the negative side, DNA transfer could facilitate the spread of antibiotic resistance genes, complicating infectious disease treatment strategies. On the positive side, DNA transfer could also create bacterial strains with improved beneficial properties, such as the remediation of petroleum-contaminated soil. Mycobacteria are a branch of the bacterial kingdom that includes both pathogens and brownfield soil-dwelling species. A novel kind of highly effective DNA transfer process, in which two cells appear to swap DNA fragments along the whole chromosome, has been described for a common laboratory mycobacterial species. The current project will identify the genes involved in that process, also testing whether distantly related mycobacteria can partake in such a transfer. The project will provide opportunities for undergraduate students and local high school teachers to gain experience in research.

Conjugal DNA transfer has been described in Mycobacterium smegmatis, generating transconjugant genomes that are mixtures of the parental strains. Distributive Conjugal Transfer (DCT) differs from traditional plasmid-based conjugation systems both in creating mosaic genomes and in mechanism, and proteins usually found in plasmid transfer systems are absent from mycobacteria. A mating identity locus (mid), which determines donor or recipient activity, has been mapped to a six-gene cluster embedded within a 25-gene locus that encodes the ESX-1 secretion apparatus. The six genes comprising mid will be analyzed for their contribution to establishing mating identity, their functional association with ESX-1 secretion, and their impact on transcriptional pathways that respond to co-culture with a mating partner. DCT will also be tested in other isolates of M. smegmatis, and in other mycobacterial species. Genome sequencing of new isolates will provide comparative data for identifying the mosaicism that is a hallmark of DCT, and provide reference sequences for transconjugants generated in the laboratory. Successful implementation of this objective will provide a broader view of the impact of DCT on gene flow in the Mycobacterium genus, and provide additional genotype/phenotype information for the critical genes of the mid locus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacterial evolution is driven by HGT, which results in the incremental acquisition of multiple tracts of foreign DNA by bacteria over an extended time. Three mechanisms mediate HGT; conjugation, transduction and transformation. Distributive Conjugal Transfer (DCT) is an entirely novel mechanism of conjugation that occurs in mycobacteria and challenges the text-book paradigms of HGT. Most remarkable is that DCT creates genome-wide mosaicism in a single event; the genomes of transconjugant progeny resemble those of meiotic recombination. This proposal has focused on the characterization of this unique process and the genetic contributions of donor and recipient cells.

Our DCT model of mycobacterial interaction previously revealed that intercellular communication occurs between donors and recipients of Mycobacterium smegmatis. We have extended this work to link two ESX (type VII) secretion systems that are both required for conjugation. Functionally distinct ESX secretion systems are found in all mycobacteria, and they serve important virulence functions in pathogenic mycobacteria. We demonstrated that SigM, an extra-cytoplasmic transcription factor, specifically activates ESX-4. No functions had been previously associated with ESX-4, most likely because it is not expressed under normal growth conditions. However, direct contact between donor and recipient cells triggers the recipient to release membrane-sequestered SigM, which rapidly induces an ESX-4-focused regulon and includes both the core esx4 locus and unlinked genes. SigM binding sites are found upstream of conserved esx4 genes throughout mycobacteria suggesting that this interaction-response network is intact and active. Contact-dependent responses similar to those identified in our model system may therefore also mediate communal processes within mycobacterial populations. We demonstrated that proteins encoded outside the esx4 core locus are actively secreted by ESX-4. Most of these proteins are required for DCT, suggesting that they either modify the host (recipient) or donor cell membranes to either provide extra-cellular signals to initiate DNA transfer or to mediate the process of DNA transfer from the donor to the recipient.

Our genetic analyses suggested that donor ability is common to all M. smegmatis isolates, while the ability to be a recipient is the exception. This is in complete contrast to oriT-mediated plasmid transfer in which all cells are recipients by default and can only become donors if they acquire transfer-associated genes. This reciprocal distinction underscores the novelty of DCT compared to the textbook oriT-plasmid-transfer systems.

Determining how bacteria sense their kin and non-kin is a novel and growing area of research, often involving quorum sensing and other extracellular signals. In particular, we wished to address how donor and recipient cells distinguish between each other to make productive mating partners, i.e. determine between self and non-self. Utilizing a variety of genetic approaches, we identified a donor gene that when mutated allowed productive crosses with a previously unproductive (kin) partner. Thus, Msmeg0070, which resides in the esx1 locus, encodes a mating identity protein, which defines kin and non-kin donors. This is, to our knowledge, the first description of social behaviour in mycobacteria.

One of the SigM-induced proteins required for DCT, Msmeg6925, contains eight Ca2+-binding motifs and is secreted via ESX-4. Msmeg6925 is highly conserved and is also regulated by SigM in other mycobacterial species, suggesting an important functional role for SigM, ESX-4 and Msmeg6925 orthologs in maintaining Ca2+ homeostasis. We have shown that two independent Ca2+ chelators (EGTA and BAPTA) abolish DCT and that addition of EGTA to the medium prevents contact-initiated induction of the SigM regulon. This supports a novel role for Ca2+ in contact-dependent DCT signaling. The role of calcium signaling in bacteria is not well understood. Our demonstration that calcium is required for contact-dependent DCT signaling suggests one role for calcium is promoting/modulating cell-cell communication and membrane integrity.
